data.name: Part One - Creating Tattoos
entries: Ob groß oder klein, einfach oder kompliziert - Tattoos sind eine hervorragende Möglichkeit, die Persönlichkeit eines Charakters zu entwickeln. Egal, ob du dem Söldner, mit dem deine Spieler sprechen, einen Hauch von Mysterium verleihen oder die tragische Hintergrundgeschichte deines Schurken näher beleuchten willst - es gibt so viele Gründe, einem Charakter ein Tattoo zu verpassen, wie es Menschen gibt, die sich selbst eines aussuchen. Auf den folgenden Seiten findest du Würfeltabellen für das Design der Tätowierung, die Platzierung, kleinere magische Eigenschaften und, wenn du möchtest, auch nützlichere magische Verzauberungen. Du kannst diese Tabellen verwenden, um Tätowierungen nach dem Zufallsprinzip zu generieren, oder du wählst das Design, die Platzierung und den Effekt aus, von dem du denkst, dass es am besten zu dem Charakter passt.

data.name: Giving Your Tattoos Magical Properties
entries: Einer der attraktivsten Aspekte einer Tätowierung für einen Abenteurer ist die Tatsache, dass sie mit magischen Eigenschaften versehen werden kann. Auf dieser Seite findest du zwei Listen mit potenziellen Verzauberungen, nämlich kleinere magische Eigenschaften und vorteilhafte Verzauberungen. Geringfügige Verzauberungen geben dem Spiel Geschmack und können dem kreativen Abenteurer in manchen Situationen hilfreich sein, bieten aber keine expliziten Spielboni. Vorteilhafte Verzauberungen hingegen geben statistische Boni, ähnlich wie gewöhnliche und ungewöhnliche wundersame Gegenstände. Wenn du einen Spielercharakter entwirfst, kann es sein, dass er zu Beginn des Spiels eine Tätowierung mit einer geringfügigen magischen Eigenschaft hat, aber es ist unwahrscheinlich, dass er zu diesem Zeitpunkt seiner Reise eine vorteilhafte Verzauberung besitzt. Als Dungeon Master kannst du Tätowierungen mit Verzauberungen wie magische Gegenstände behandeln, indem du sie als Belohnung gibst oder von den Spielern verlangst, sie auf irgendeine Weise zu verdienen. In einem Dorf von Halblingen kann es zum Beispiel einen Meister-Tätowierer geben, der nur mit denjenigen arbeitet, die der Gemeinschaft in irgendeiner Weise geholfen haben.

entries.name: Advantageous Enchantments
entries: Wirf einen Würfel, um die Verzauberung des Tattoos zu bestimmen. Diese Verzauberungen sind signifikant genug, um den Tätowierungen sichtbare Eigenschaften zu verleihen, die von denen erkannt werden können, die mit dieser Art von Verzauberungen vertraut sind. Die spezifische Art der Verzauberung kann mit einer DC15-Untersuchungsprobe oder einer DC10-Arkana-Probe ermittelt werden. Da diese Verzauberungen ihre magische Kraft von ihrem Besitzer beziehen, ist eine normale Kreatur auf zwei Tätowierungen mit bedeutenden Verzauberungen beschränkt. Andernfalls riskiert die Kreatur unerwünschte Nebeneffekte wie Erschöpfung, unbeabsichtigte magische Konsequenzen oder dass die magischen Tätowierungen beginnen, sich untereinander zu streiten.

data.name: Part Two - Getting Tattooed
entries: Once you've finalised the design, chosen the enchantment and raised the necessary funds, it's time to get tattooed. In order to be tattooed you must find an artist willing to do the work,travel to their studio and spend the time and gold necessary to tattoo the piece. The cost and duration of a tattooing session is dependent on several factors, including the size, shape and complexity of the tattoo, the location of the studio, whether the tattoo is enchanted and your relationship with the artist. Exact figures should be decided by the DM, but the following pages should provide some guidelines for setting values, and inspiration for unique tattoo artists and studios.

entries.name: Duration
entries: Even the smallest tattoos will take at least an hour to complete . The following table assigns tattoos a size based on there location on the body, and suggests the length of time it would take to create a tattoo of this size, however the time taken will also depend on the skill of an artist and the complexity of the design. Enchanting a tattoo will take an additional hour after the completion of the artwork to ensure the magic is effective and permanent.

entries.caption: Optional Caption
rows: Tiny
Behind the Ear, On a Finger
1-2 Hours
Small
Hand, Foot, Ankle, Scalp, Face, The Back of the Neck
2-3 Hours
Medium

3-5 Hours
Large

5-8 Hours

entries: After being tattooed, a creature must wait until the tattoo is completely healed (1d4 days for each hour the tattoo took to be completed) before they can be tattooed again. The creature can begin to gain the benefits of an enchanted tattoo after they complete a long rest, provided the tattoo does not become infected (see the rules for Infection).

entries.name: Cost
entries: Tattoo artists may charge a flat rate for a piece, or by hour of work. The rate of pay will vary from artist to artist, and some may require payment other than gold, or require additional payment or services. The following table provides guideline for pricing based on the complexity of the tattoo.

rows: Basic (Simple Line Art, Black Ink Only, No Shading)
10gp/hr
Simple (Some Shading or Solid Black Sections, Some Detail, Black Ink Only)
15gp/hr
Fine (Some Colour, Shading, Fine Detail)
20gp/hr
Grand (Full Colour, Complicated Designs, Very Fine Detail, Hidden Elements, Realism or Other Specialty Styles)
50gp/hr

entries: Enchanting a tattoo incurs additional cost. In general, bestowing a tattoo with a minor magical property increases its complexity by tier, i.e. a basic tattoo would be considered simple, a simple tattoo fine, and so on. Imbuing a tattoo with an advantageous enchantment will usually double the cost of the work.

entries.name: Infection
entries: When getting a tattoo, there is always a risk of infection. This depends on the cleanliness of the tattoo studio, and how much care is taken over the tattoo when it heals. On completing their first long rest after being tattooed, the tattooed creature must make a constitution saving throw. The DC of this throw is dependant on the conditions under which the tattoo was given, shown in the table below.

rows: Spotless
DC5
Clean
DC7
Average
DC10
Grimy
DC12
Dirty
DC17
Filthy
DC20

entries: On a succesful save, the wound resists infection. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d4 poison damage, and is Poisoned until the wound is fully healed, (1d4 days for each hour the tattoo took to be completed) or until the infection is cured.

data.name: Tattoo Artists
entries: Tattoo artists can be flavourful NPCs, plot hooks, antagonists or anything else you can imagine. The following tables can be used to generate a random tattoo artist and their studio, or as inspiration to help you create your own characters.

entries.name: Studio
entries: A tattoo artists studio is where they work, and can be as much a reflection of themselves as the tattoos they design. Studios are usually located in cities, where large populations provide them with plenty of business, and are traditionally associated with the seedier parts of town, but an artist can set up shop anywhere.

rows: Spotless

entries.name: Artists
entries: The person actually doing the tattooing. Artists can vary wildly in age, demeanour and history, but are often figures of mystery or intrigue, even within the communities they call home.

rows: They hum constantly as they work
They close their eyes as they work, only opening them once they've finished

They sign all of their pieces with their initials
They have no patience for anyone who is hesistant or unsure

They will not let anyone see the tattoo until it is done

They take a lock of hair from everyone they tattoo

They love animals, and keep several pets in their studio, all of which are allowed to roam freely about the room
They are an ex-soldier, and will only tattoo that can sufficiently prove their valour
They will give you the tattoo that they think will suit you, regardless of what you asked them for

table.name: Tattoo Artist Quirk
table.caption: Tattoo Artist Quirk
intro: Add a little extra personality to your character by rolling a d20 to determine a quirk of their tattooing.
rows: They hum constantly as they work
They close their eyes as they work, only opening them once they've finished
They work in absolute silence, stoppingcompletely if their subject speaks
They are afraid to tattoo unless they are blind drunk
Their tattoo machine looks as if it was cobbled together from scrap
They refuse monetary payment, they will only work in exchange for secrets
They communicate only in an unexpected language
They chat incessantly about whatever pops into their head
They sign all of their pieces with their initials
They have no patience for anyone who is hesistant or unsure
They won't tattoo anyone until they've gotten to know them over a cup of tea
They will not let anyone see the tattoo until it is done
They stop to look out of the window for inspiration every ten minutes
They take a lock of hair from everyone they tattoo
They flirt constatntly as they work, but never pursue a relationship
They are so heavily tattooed themselves that you can only determine individual designs after lengthy study
They abhor the sight of blood, and so will only work remotely, using mage hand from another room
They love animals, and keep several pets in their studio, all of which are allowed to roam freely about the room
They are an ex-soldier, and will only tattoo that can sufficiently prove their valour
They will give you the tattoo that they think will suit you, regardless of what you asked them for
